TEXT.CONTENT: In order to build with CodeWarrior, a project file is needed. The following pages will guide you through the process of creating a project.
Select the derivative you would like to use:
Choose your default connection:
Select the derivative you would like to use:
Choose your default connection:
Would you like to have the support of XGATE?.
Please choose the set of languages to be supported initially. You can make multiple selections.
Add existing files to the project
Rapid Application Development Options:
Which level of startup code do you want to use? Select 'minimal startup code' for best code density.
Which memory model shall be used?
Select the floating point format supported. Select 'None' for best code density.
Which level of startup code do you want to use? Select 'minimal startup code' for best code density.
Which memory model shall be used?
Select the floating point format supported. Select 'None' for best code density.
Select if all non-constant data fit in the non-paged RAM or all constants and the code fit into the non-paged flash
Memory Mapping
Use both ranges 0x4000-0x7FFF and 0xC000-0xFFFF for placing code and constants?
Use MemoryBanker for:
Select the XGATE Floating point support
Select which memory will be used to store XGATE code
Select the XGATE Floating point support
Select which memory will be used to store XGATE code
Do you want to use the OSEKturbo operating system in your project?
Do you want to create a project set up for PC-lint(TM)?

WIZARDELEMENT.name: Language
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Using only one single assembly source file with absolute assembly. No support for relocatable assembly or linker.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: Language
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Relocatable Assembly supports to split up the application into multiple assembly source files. The source files are linked together using the linker.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: Language
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: This will set up your application with an ANSI-C compliant startup code (doing initialization of global variables).

WIZARDELEMENT.name: Language
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: This will set up your application with a C++ startup code (doing global class object initialization).

WIZARDELEMENT.name: Target
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Freescale Full Chip Simulation with simulation of on-chip peripherals. Later on in the debugger you can switch to hardware debugging.

GENERATEFILE.INPUT: // At startup the commands written below will be executed

WIZARDELEMENT.name: Target
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Connect to P&E USB BDM Multilink. This development tool allows access to the Background Debug Mode (BDM) on Freescale HCS12(X) microcontrollers to directly control the target's execution, read/write registers and memory values, debug code on the processor, and program internal or external FLASH memory devices.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: Target
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION:
Connect to P&E Cyclone via USB port. This flexible tool is designed for in-circuit flash programming, debugging, and testing of Freescale HCS12(X) microcontrollers in development and production environments.
The Cyclone can be operated in interactive or batch mode. Once loaded with data it can be disconnected and operated manually in stand-alone mode via the LCD menu and control buttons. The Cyclone has over 3 MB of non-volatile memory, which allows the onboard storage of multiple programming images. When connected to a computer for programming or loading it can communicate via Ethernet, USB, or serial interfaces.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: Target
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION:
Connect to P&E Cyclone via serial port. This flexible tool is designed for in-circuit flash programming, debugging, and testing of Freescale HCS12(X) microcontrollers in development and production environments.
The Cyclone can be operated in interactive or batch mode. Once loaded with data it can be disconnected and operated manually in stand-alone mode via the LCD menu and control buttons. The Cyclone has over 3 MB of non-volatile memory, which allows the onboard storage of multiple programming images. When connected to a computer for programming or loading it can communicate via Ethernet, USB, or serial interfaces.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: Target
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION:
Connect to P&E Cyclone via Ethernet port. This flexible tool is designed for in-circuit flash programming, debugging, and testing of Freescale HCS12(X) microcontrollers in development and production environments.
The Cyclone can be operated in interactive or batch mode. Once loaded with data it can be disconnected and operated manually in stand-alone mode via the LCD menu and control buttons. The Cyclone has over 3 MB of non-volatile memory, which allows the onboard storage of multiple programming images. When connected to a computer for programming or loading it can communicate via Ethernet, USB, or serial interfaces.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: PrcExp
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: No device initialization code is generated. Only generates startup code. See readme.txt in project how Processor Expert can be enabled (if not done here).

WIZARDELEMENT.name: PrcExp
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: The tool can generate initialization code for on-chip peripherals, interrupt vector table and template for interrupt vector service routines.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: PrcExp
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Processor Expert can generate for you all the device initialization code. It includes many low-level drivers.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: PCLint
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Lint tools can find common programming mistakes or suspicious lines in source code by analyzing it. PC-lint(TM) is a product from Gimpel Software. You need the PC-lint(TM) software from Gimpel installed in order to use the CodeWarrior plugin. This will add an additional Target to the project with the name PC-Lint. You need a professional license in order to use the PC-Lint plugin.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: PCLint
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Lint tools can find common programming mistakes or suspicious lines in source code by analyzing it. PC-lint(TM) is a product from Gimpel Software. You need the PC-lint(TM) software from Gimpel installed in order to use the CodeWarrior plugin. You can enable PC-lint(TM) later by manually cloning a target and changing the linker to PC-lint linker.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: XGATE_yes_no
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: The created project will only contain source code for the HCS12X. However it is possible to manually add XGATE support later.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: XGATE_yes_no
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: The created project will contain source code for the HCS12X and the XGATE.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: XGATE_MEMORY_TYPE
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: The created project will contain source code for the HCS12X and the XGATE. The HCS12X code copies the XGATE code from flash into ram and then configures the XGATE.

MACROLIST.MACRO: ; for other XGATE segments to be always copied to RAM ; CopyToRam XGATE_CODE_RAM

WIZARDELEMENT.name: XGATE_MEMORY_TYPE
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: The created project will contain source code for the HCS12X and the XGATE. The XGATE will execute out of the flash. Note that this setup does not work with the initial L40V maskset of the MC9S12XDP512.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: XGATE_MEMORY_TYPE
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Placement in both flash and RAM can occur when placing all of the XGATE code+data in only RAM would consume too much of the RAM. In this case, the user can put higher priority code in the RAM, and lower priority in the slower flash.

MACROLIST.MACRO: XGATE_CODE_RAM: SECTION ; Sample fast handler placed to RAM:

XGATE_CODE: SECTION ; Normal handler placed to FLASH:
ALIGN 2

WIZARDELEMENT.name: XGATE_ENABLE
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: The created project will contain source code for the HCS12X and the XGATE. The HCS12X code copies the XGATE code from flash into ram and then configures the XGATE.

MACROLIST.MACRO: INCLUDE "xgate.inc" XREF XGATE_Counter ; shared data with XGATE.
; Two stacks are in XGATE core3 XGATE_STK_L: SECTION LowStack ds.w 1 XGATE_STK_H: SECTION HighStack ds.w 1

BRA SetupXGATE
CopyLoop: BEQ EndCopyLoop PSHD Loop: GLDAA 1,Y+ ; load a single code byte from flash STAA 1,X+ ; store it DECW 0,SP BNE Loop PULD EndCopyLoop:RTS
CopyToRam: macro LDY #GLOBAL (__SEG_START_\1) ; we use GPAGE for the src (to flash) LDAB #GLOBAL_PAGE(__SEG_START_\1) STAB GPAGE_ADR LDX # __SEG_RELOCATE_TO_\1 ; and RPAGE to the RAM LDAB #PAGE(__SEG_RELOCATE_TO_\1) STAB RPAGE_ADR
LDD # __SEG_SIZE_\1 BSR CopyLoop endm
SetupXGATE: ifndef __RUN_XGATE_OUT_OF_FLASH ; do we need to copy the XGATE code into the RAM? ; copy the XGATE program code to the RAM CopyToRam XGATE_CODE endif ; __RUN_XGATE_OUT_OF_FLASH

; init variables shared with XGATE CLRW XGATE_Counter ; init counter for the XGATE
; initialize the XGATE vector block and ; set the XGVBR register to its start address LDX #GLOBAL(XGATE_VectorTable) STX $386 ; XGVBR
; switch software trigger 0 interrupt to XGATE MOVB #(SOFTWARETRIGGER0_VEC & $F0), INT_CFADDR MOVB #$80|$01, INT_CFDATA0 + ((SOFTWARETRIGGER0_VEC & $0F) >> 1)
; enable XGATE mode and interrupts MOVW #$FBC1, XGMCTL ; XGE | XGFRZ | XGIE
; force execution of software trigger 0 handler MOVW #$0101, XGSWT

; init variables shared with XGATE CLRW XGATE_Counter ; init counter for the XGATE
; initialize the XGATE vector block and ; set the XGVBR register to its start address LDX #GLOBAL(XGATE_VectorTable) STX $386 ; XGVBR
; switch software trigger 0 interrupt to XGATE MOVB #(SOFTWARETRIGGER0_VEC & $F0), INT_CFADDR MOVB #$80|$01, INT_CFDATA0 + ((SOFTWARETRIGGER0_VEC & $0F) >> 1)
; set XGATE core 3 two stacks ; when changing your derivative to non-core3 one please remove next nine lines LDAB #1 STAB XGISPSEL LDX #GLOBAL(LowStack + 2) STX XGISP31 LDAB #2 STAB XGISPSEL LDX #GLOBAL(HighStack + 2) STX XGISP74 CLR XGISPSEL
; enable XGATE mode and interrupts MOVW #$FBC1, XGMCTL ; XGE | XGFRZ | XGIE
; force execution of software trigger 0 handler MOVW #$0101, XGSWT

WIZARDELEMENT.name: osek
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: This will set up your project with OSEKturbo.

MACROLIST.MACRO: StartOS(Mode); /* jump to OSEKturbo OS startup */

WIZARDELEMENT.name: osek
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: No operating system support is added.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: StartupCode
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: This will just initialize the stack pointer and call the main function. No initialization of global variables is done. This gives the best speed/code density and a fast startup time, but the application code has to care about variable initialization itself. Note: The minimal startup code is not ANSI compliant as ANSI does require variable initialization.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: StartupCode
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: This will perform an ANSI compliant startup code: it initializes global variables/objects and calls the application main routine.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: FLPoint
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Don't use floating point support.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: FLPoint
WIZARDELEMENT.term: float is IEEE32, double is IEEE32
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: All float and double variables are 32bit/IEEE32.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: FLPoint
WIZARDELEMENT.term: float is IEEE32, double is IEEE64
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Float variables are 32bit/IEEE32, double variables are 64bit/IEEE64.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemoryModel
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Choose this if you are not sure will non-constant data fit in the non-paged RAM or constants and the code fit into the non-paged flash

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemoryModel
WIZARDELEMENT.term: All non-constant data fit in the non-paged RAM
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Choose this in either one of the following situations: - Your non-constant data fit into 12k and you do not plan on accessing non-paged RAM areas through RPAGE. If you choose this and still do accesses through the RPAGE register the compiler generated code may be incorrect. Accesses through RPAGE include accesses through __rptr-qualified pointers and accessed to variables defined in __RPAGE_SEG sections. - You have less than 8k non-constant data. If this is the case you can also do accesses through RPAGE. Warning: this will induce non-ANSI behavior in the compiler. When accessing constant data by means of pointer to non-const the compiler may produce code that will not meet the required functionality.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemoryModel
WIZARDELEMENT.term: All constants and the code fit into the non-paged flash
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Choose this in either one of the following situations: - Your constants and code fit into 48k of flash and you do not plan on accessing non-paged flash areas through PPAGE. If you choose this and still do accesses through the PPAGE register (e.g. calling a far function) the code may be incorrect. - You have less than 32k constants and code. If this is the case you can also do accesses through PPAGE. Warning: this will induce non-ANSI behavior in the compiler: when accessing non-constant data by means of pointer to const the compiler may produce code that will not meet the required functionality. This is also true when accessing constant members of structures that are not constant by means of pointer to const.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemoryMapping
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Maps accesses to 0x4000-0x7FFF to 0x0F_C000-0x0F_FFFF in the global memory space (RAM area). More RAM will be available in the local memory map. Note: It is not possible to use MemoryBanker with this kind of mapping.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemoryMapping
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Maps accesses to 0x4000-0x7FFF to 0x7F_4000-0x7F_7FFF in the global memory space (FLASH). More flash will be available in the local memory map.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemoryMapping
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Maps accesses to 0x4000-0x7FFF to 0x14_4000-0x14_7FFF in the global memory space (external access). Note: It is not possible to use MemoryBanker with this kind of mapping.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemoryModel
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: This allows you to use both mentioned ranges at the cost of disabling the optimization that changes JSR's into BSR's (the project settings will include the following compiler option: -Onb=b). If your project will include libraries (other than the ones provided by Freescale) they too need to be compiled with this option.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemoryModel
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Only range 0xC000-0xFFFF will be used for placing code and constants. If you want to use range 0x4000-0x7FFF too for placing data only you can edit the linker parameter file after the project is generated. If you want to place code too in range 0x4000-0x7FFF, you can either choose "Yes" here or later add -Onb=b as a compiler option, add the corresponding runtime library to the project and also recompile all the other libraries your project might include with this option (in addition to changing the linker parameter file).

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemoryModel
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: MemoryBanker is an automation tool that optimizes the layout of code and data in order to minimize the application's memory footprint. In the first pass it gathers information about the application and generates the layout, while in the second pass it generates the optimized code. It can be used to generate an optimal distribution for functions, for data or for both functions and data.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemoryModel
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: MemoryBanker is an automation tool that optimizes the layout of code and data in order to minimize the application's memory footprint. In the first pass it gathers information about the application and generates the layout, while in the second pass it generates the optimized code. It can be used to generate an optimal distribution for functions, for data or for both functions and data.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemModel
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: The Small memory model is best suited if both the code and the data do fit into the 64 kB address space. By default all variables and functions are accessed with 16 bit addresses. The compiler does support banked functions or paged variables in this memory model, however all accesses have to be explicitly handled. The small memory model should be used for all derivatives with less than 64k.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemModel
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: The Banked memory model is using banked function calls by default. The default data access however is still 16 bit. Because the overhead of the far function call is not very large, this memory model suits all applications with more than 64k code. Data paging can be used in the banked memory model, however all far objects and pointers to them have to be specially declared.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemModel
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: The Large memory model supports both code banking and data paging by default. But especially the data paging does cause a great overhead and therefore should only be used with care. The overhead is significant with respect to both code size and speed. If it is possible to manually use far accesses to the data, which does not fit into the 64 bit address space, then the banked memory model should be used instead.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: MemModel
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: The Custom memory model allows you to configure the project to support both code banking and data paging. It provides the user with some options which allow the build tools to optimize accesses and generate more efficient code than the Large memory model, without the need for the programmer to manually place data. Note that any application can be written using the Banked memory model instead, and the generated code will always be more efficient than just using the custom memory model. The cost is that the user must manually place data that does not fit in the first 64k by means of pragmas.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: HC12_FLPoint
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Don't use floating point support for the HC12.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: HC12_FLPoint
WIZARDELEMENT.term: float is IEEE32, double is IEEE32
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: All float and double variables are 32bit/IEEE32 for the HC12.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: HC12_FLPoint
WIZARDELEMENT.term: float is IEEE32, double is IEEE64
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Float variables are 32bit/IEEE32, double variables are 64bit/IEEE64 for the HC12.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: XGATE_FLPoint
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: Don't use floating point support for the XGATE.

WIZARDELEMENT.name: XGATE_FLPoint
WIZARDELEMENT.term: float is IEEE32, double is IEEE32
WIZARDELEMENT.DESCRIPTION: All float and double variables are 32bit/IEEE32 for the XGATE.

GENERATEFILE.INPUT: // At startup the commands written below will be executed
// Before load the commands written below will be executed
// After load the commands written below will be executed $$MAP4000_RAM_FOR_DEBUGGER$$
// After reset the commands written below will be executed
This is a dummy entry for the map file. The correct input will be placed after the first link process.
// Before programming the flash, the commands written below will be executed
// After programming the flash, the commands written below will be executed
